I actually really liked two 3rds of this film. The time travel was done really well and the motivation was great. The way the heist was executed was awesome. Got some superb character development and arks to watch. "I'm still worthy!" was a favourite line for sure. The hawkeye and black widow scene was severly lacking in chemistry but that's ok. Plot worked fine. It was all going well, until...In the last act, it just turned into another US military propaganda ending. "I am Ironman." Come on. Perhaps Americans can't see it because it is so prolific in that culture, but it sticks out like a sore thumb from where I'm sitting. "Captain America" stands against the army of invaders alone, proud. It's a great comic book moment but it's just all too relevent to current affairs to be entertaining. Then America leads the world against the baddies and they murder everyone in the name of peace. Ironman gets the gaunlet at the end and instead of thinking of a genius 'only tony stark' character ark completion 11/10 moment where he finds a way to create peace without killing anyone. He just asserts "I am Ironman" (military industrial complex personified then) and murders the invaders! How is he any different from Thanos?1/3 of the film is spent mourning the 50% of living beings that died, and then Tony just does the same back to them. So...what is the moral here? The moral of the story is this: murder is ok if you kill ALL of them. Then they can't come back at you and you win because you write history. It's the Amalocites all over again. Given that this is a 10 year long project ending, I hoped they would be leaving a lasting and pertinent message for the future generation but instead, it's just the same old war-mongering ending as always.Humans may never learn that violence only ever begets more violence. There is unequivically no such thing as violence in the name of peace. Do not be fooled.
Best Avengers & MCU movie ever.This is a crossover that you will remember forget.The visual effects,fighting scene everything was awesome.

There were EASILY 45-minutes of this film that should have ended up on the editing room floor. All the things I couldn't stand about the Harry Potter and the LOTR worlds, namely the melodrama and seriousness, have been splattered all over my cinematic universe. When, (spoiler redacted) dies, I was seriously thinking, "I know (spoiler redacted) is a big effing deal but he/she has been in the process of dying for 11 hours and 5 minutes." That was the thing about all the major deaths too. Pretty much all the heroes who fall have frustratingly long funereal sequences, as if a real person died. If (spoiler redacted) had died in real life during the production of the flick, then, by all means, have a sappy, meandering funeral scene for him. However, (spoiler redacted) is alive and VERY WELL; so, that funeral was a ridiculous waste of time. I would have enjoyed spending that time watching well-executed action sequences and superhero shenanigans. Not to mention, these deaths are not even vaguely sad to me. The MCU has countless avenues by which they may resurrect ostensibly any character offed; so, yeah, with that in mind, give me a break with all the very "DC" gloom. My last beef is with Captain Marvel. Seems to me she could have ended that mess pretty damn quickly. Instead, she decided to disappear for 2/3 of the movie, visit the worst barber shop in the galaxy while she was gone, and then reappear just in time to demonstrate how easy this whole ordeal could have been handled had she only stuck around in the first place. It's kind of stupid to have her in the movie, because the MCU has adorned her with such omnipotence that no foe stands a chance. She's like bringing a bazooka to a water-balloon fight. One second, everyone's splashing around, having a good time. Then, Danvers shows up and the whole neighborhood ends up dead. She's just too powerful to be cinematically useful. Movies featuring Carol Danvers that are longer than 30 minutes are not really being honest. Overall, "Endgame" was exhausting. Somebody had to tackle the undertaking of its creation. In that task, the cast and crew were largely successful; but, still, something was missing. Maybe Paul Bettany was the Avengers' lucky charm.

The slow pace in the beginning can surely be overlooked considering what's in stock during the second half of the movie. Although I'm not a vehement Marvel fan, it's apposite to say this movie a befitting end to the Thanos saga. Respect to Russo brothers for being able to pull off an onerous task of concluding the tapestry MCU has created over the decade.These movies are basically an end to 21 movies. So, the payoffs were huge. I loved that Captain used Mjolnir. Thor was most ridiculous for me in both Infinity War and Endgame. The tone of the character doesn't work somehow after Ragnarok, either he's cracking joke after Thanos kills Asgardians and Loki or he's being a self-pitying alcoholic post the snap. Captain Marvel does what she was introduced to do in this universe, she pops up where it is convenient to the plot. The fact that her character had less screen time was apposite to me considering her underwhelming origin movie. The surprising character was Clint. Even though his screen time in previous movies is less, the transformation of an uber agent after losing everything to become a ruthless killer in search of solace/purpose is intriguing. Ronan kind of reminded me of John Wick. But when Clint is given hope to undo what's done by the mad titan, you can see the compassionate and kind side of him; the scene between him and Agent Romanoff is heart-warming and poignant at the same time. The humane nature explored in Clint's character made is supremely engaging. I wanted more screen time for Doctor Strange so that I can hear more about his one in fourteen million possibilities. Professor Hulk was a fun character. And Iron Man sacrificing himself was an audacious move for the writers. I was reminded of a dialogue by Kylo Ren in The Last Jedi when he says to Ray, "Let the past die.Kill it, if you have to." This movie is more rewarding to the MCU fans. It is a love letter to the original Avengers. The makers have done everything which was warranted to close this chapter spanning a decade.

I would like to review it without spoilers, but I know I won't be able to... So here is my list:Liked:
* Hulk. Like all others, except Captain America, this original avenger has a very good growth arc. He is the embodiment of the inner division so many of us feel (wonder if this was the inspiration for the character - to give the inner rage, inner "i just want to smash things", which most of us so often have to suppress of keep deeply hidden due to our social role, mask). This Hulk is the result of inner peace that is so hard to find - just be a friend to yourself. The scene where current Hulk tries to be the Smash-all-things Hulk is very funny because it stresses the big inner differences between them. Just like the remark: "I wear shirts now". It uses very well the point in timespace when clothes became a symbol of "being civilised".* Black Widow and Hawkeye. These two have one of the best friendships on screen of all times. The love they have for each other could be easily felt in their every scene over the various films. I already saw some complains from a very bias group about he fate of Black Widow, but I assume that they are the kind of people where personal agenda wins over the character consistency. Back Widow has only one family - Hawkeye's family. She was the only one (except Fury, but he knew because of work) who knew about Hawkeye's family. They even named their kid after her, so you know that they each considers one another very closer. Closer than anyone else. And they will do everything for one another. Their main scene showed that very well too. There is no way Black Widow would have let her sister in law and her nephews and nieces live without a father. Their friendship is the goal how friendships between man and a woman should be portrayed. And we for sure don't have them enough on the screen.* Iron Man Tony Stark. His story is so symbolic in this one. Everything started with him and ended with him. His unwillingness to go and leave the family he has and the guilt he felt after Peter Parker turned to dust in his arms. Everything was great. Such a turn around from the playboy we first saw to a two women man. Plus, I doubt there is anyone else who is so much Tony Stark in real life as Robert Downey Jr. You will be missed as Tony Stark.* Captain Marvel. As expected, she didn't have a lot of screen time, but came to the final fight. Was she the key in defeating Thanos (or, more precisely, helping Tony to do it)? Debatable. But the visual effects around her are always very nice. I liked that she (and, sort of, was) the key character. This film wasn't about her or any other new character. This was all about the original 6 and including her would have taken that away.* Captain America. For me he is the most boring character. He is already fully developed in his first film and afterwards he doesn't change. On one hand, it is very nice to see such an unbendable morale and code, on the other hand it's a bit boring. His story end though rases for me a lot of questions that have to do with time travel paradox.* Thor. Nailed it!
Dislike:
* No Fury and Carol Danvers scenes. Seriously. Their first meeting after Fury was brought back should have been epic. Especially if Hill was by the side and has Fury something like: "Nick, what just happened?". The eye Carol should have given to Fury, the remark about "everybody calls me Fury". I also doubt that he would have held up his comments about her hair and her - about his eye. Such a wonderful opportunity missed.

After having watched all 22 movies in a tight timeframe (10 days), I have several different thoughts and opinions on the MCU franchise. Since this review is for Avengers: Endgame, I will keep my perspective focused on that movie. My favorite character of all time was always Hulk. He was always the "secret weapon" and the critical member of the team that could be relied on for tearing stuff up. Ironman was a close second. After watching Endgame, however, the roles for the best Avenger for me has switched. "Endgame" really scored for me on an emotional level. There were some "ah-ha" moments and some tearful moments as well. I also grew angry at times. Having all these emotional reactions in a 3 hour time frame is not unusual but I had these feelings even as I exited and drove home. Definitely a great movie. I must admit that all 22 movies in the lineup were not all great (I think only 5 would get a repeat watch from me) and some of the character development waned in some movies. In "Endgame", I couldn't have major respect for some characters (ie Captain Marvel) because I don't think this character had as much invested as the others over the years even though she was vital to the end war against Thanos. I also loved Scarlett Witch but I think she needs her own character movie. I just wanted to know more about her. The CGI was very well done! I thought Hulk was so cute as he closely resembled his human counterpart, Dr. Banner. I appreciated the return of all the beloved characters to end the fight against Thanos. I did think there were a few plot holes (such as the Ancient One, who is supposed to be all-knowing and all-seeing, not being able to see why Hulk was there to retrieve the Time Stone). Overall, the movie was worth the 3 hours and $15 I invested to see it. The clink of the metal at the end of the credits may signify the return of Ironman (not sure how but it'll be interesting). (On a side note, I wish Angela Bassett had a longer appearance in the movie but I get why she wasn't).

"I created this account only to give this movie a 1", or "I give this a 5 rating but am voting it a 1 just to lower the undeserved high rating", and of course all the comedians and trolls and the holier than thou of moviedom that give various reasons for trying to adjust this movie's merits, or lack thereof. These are the kind of disappointing reviews I am writing about. Stop adjusting and come to the realization that you didn't get what you wanted from it. Others did.Here's what I think. There was a good mix of action and dialogue. You know, dialogue, the part that tells the story? The CG and non-CG special effects worked for me. The story was a little weak. Time travel is a subject that is still fiction, so I feel no need to try and pick apart the theoretical inconsistencies. Some make the comment that there was too much going on in trying to bring the whole MCU into this movie and that the idea may have been a bad one. Now this is the kind of comment that is useful in a review. I won't say more, since just about anything else could be a spoiler. It was a good 6 out of 10, so I am giving it a 6.

These were the 3 best characters of the movie and did the emotional lifting with perfect performance by the actors. The final battle is like a true comic book with amazing 'wow' moments. The first 2 hours are a little bit to comedic for my liking (thor and bruce are apparently incapable of acting serious for 1 minute, which i didn't really like). But what makes up for that is the insane amount of references to previous films which is just amazing, fan service everywhere. The other supporting cast are great as well, Nebula, Rocket and ant man are great in this movie. I think it will take quite some time before a superhero movie thÃ­s good will come out.

I see most people who have decided to review Avengers: Endgame thought the movie was horrible, so I think this film deserves a better rep for those who have yet to see it. Endgame is the conclusion we have all been waiting for from the MCU, and personally I think Endgame did a brilliant job at giving the audience something to cry about, laugh about, smile about, and just love.
Being a huge fan of the Marvel film franchise, I did not think that the ending this movie gave us was lacklustre, or less exciting than Infinity War. Personally, I would have to say this movie was even better than Infinity War, most likely due to the fact that it is the grand finale of all these movies, but honestly the movie was just that memorable.
There was never a moment where I was bored during this 3 hour film. Whilst most people snark at the idea of sitting down for that long for a movie, once I had watched it I fully understood why it had to be that way. To finish this big of a legacy takes a lot of time, and within those 3 hours I could just feel myself submerge into the wider MCU one last time (needless to say, there will be plenty more Marvel movies), and I definitely enjoyed every part of it.
This movie is definitely worth a watch if you like action, romance, heartbreak, and just an overall good story line. Avengers: Endgame definitely deserves it's praise and so much more.

The end of the saga couldn't have been better.

Avengers Endgame: ReviewBlockbusters like this only come once in a generation. After the epic Infinity War Marvel opted for a more melancholy film. One where the heroes we had connected to lost.The Characters:
Our characters are broken. Destroyed by their failures from the previous film and trying to cope with what happened. Each heroes coping mechanism is different and fallows the characterization all ready established in the other films. Building off what was already established in previous films.
For me Hawkeye is one of the best characters in the film. His ark is set up from scene one. He starts and what he believes as someone who is unredeemable. Then gets a shot at redemption and thinks he will sacrifices himself for the crimes he committed. Instead it was Natasha who ends up sacrificing herself. Now with this new found purpose to live and keep going. This is helped through Jermy Renners acting. His acting throughout helps create as strong emotional core of the film.Acting:
Similar to Infinity War the acting is top notch. Standouts are Karen Gillian as Nebula and Robert Downy Jr. as Iron Man. All the acting is great, from the comedic Thor, to the understated Black Widow who is trying to redeem herself in this new world.Direction:
Joe and Anthony Ruso had there work cut out for them. They directed the film exquisitely creating iconic shots and emotionally impacting moments. The film can do dramatic and make it interesting to look at and watch. The action as well is amazing and similar to the massive battles from Lord Of The Rings.Writing and Story:
If you spent at least 5 minutes on the internet after infinity war you probably saw someone's theory. Every theory out there was wrong but not better than the film we got (something that The Last Jedi suffered from in some peoples opinion).
The smart snappy comedy that the MCU is known for is throughout and helps make the films not all a depressing movie that isn't entertaining.
The writing also do great at subverting audience expectations. Going in a direction that wasn't expected. This is shown perfectly in the first few minutes. Everyone expects the heroes to use the stones and bring all the dead hero's back. Instead the heroes have to wait to get there redemption.Ending A Franchise:
Ending a series in a satisfying and fulfilling ending is hard. But when done right is magical. Look at Return Of The King the film was the end of the LOTR series in a satisfying way. Endgame does this to giving an ending to the story of Tony Stark and Steve Rodgers in a satisfying and conclusive ending. Bring the ending that no one expected and didn't feel rushed.Conclusion:
The film is a blockbuster of the highest caliber. One of both emotion and action bringing everything together in a satisfying conclusive way.Final Score:
11/10

Hmmmm I tried to go into the movie without high expectations, well as much as I could so I wouldn't say I was disappointed but it just wasn't was good as it could have been.Don't want to give anything away so this will be brief but the pluses are great action pieces, plenty of time with our favourite avengers and it ties up all the loose ends perfectly!The issues:
Its about an hour too long, takes way to long to get the motive and planning out the way before our hero's actually get about fixing the problem.Similar to Return of the King after the climax of the movie we spend far to long summing everything up and being all reflective.There are some odd character developments which feel a bit like Last Jedi type changes - hmm is it a Disney thing.It does struggle a bit to involve everyone at times - lacking the concise sharpness of many of the stand alone character movies.
Overall it is a good movie for sure it's just not as awesome as the likes of Black Panther, Ragnorok or Captain Marvel.

Historically speaking, the final movie of any movie series is either really good or really bad. Marvel Cinematic Universe with Avengers: Endgame - the end of an era - made the best look bad. It is one of the most satisfying movies ever.Captain America turns out to be worthy for Thor's Mjolnir and saves him mid-fight. This was important for Cap's character as he is the righteous person, but Thor's fans will feel bad at this.Endgame has been the best in every aspect but the time-travel related complexities. Marvel actually killed it by introducing a new time-travel timeline type, given that every other movie uses one of the conventional types. But they just skipped over some important details. We've seen dozens of minutes of screen-time spent on the birth of Vision and the Iron suit and the mini-arc reactor in the previous MCU movies, why not the time machine? This oversight in explaining the time travel bothers me. The whole infinity 'war' is 5 hrs long. This is a small setback, they should've gotten deeper into the time machine stuff.That 4-second Peggy Carter and Steve Rogers scene was one of the most pleasing things. I would LOVE to see more of Nat. But she's getting a film all about herself, and that settles things. Loki didn't return but we have already mourned for him.

-First of all I want to thank Stan Lee for the whole thing! and I also thank Marvel for making the movies .-This movie ends most of the story lines they have made so far for their characters.-Endgame has more sentimental scenes compared with Infinity war which got more actions and suspense; and I praise them both.-One thing that I don't like about Endgame is about Thanos. Writers should have gave him more chance. But after all Thanos finished his job in infinity war and he won!
P.S: Endgame was more like a "Oh! Our heroes really lost?! We can't let that happen! We must find someway to let them win!"P.S.2: Nat sacrificed herself with no condition! She deserved at least a memorial! :'(

The MCU movies have been not just about the storyline they portray. They were the last frontline of cinema in times of on demand tv shows, at least from my recent experiences at the movies in a rural area of Germany.
People setting alarm clocks for ticket sales and sitting through double/triple features after midnight, this is when movie magic really happens for me and I fear that this is the culmination and the end of this kind of cinematic culture. Nothing like this has been done before and it is uncertain if we will ever see such an epic journey of interwoven films again like this.This is a thank you to anyone involved in the creation of these film, since I am grateful for this experience and always was looking forward to the next chapter in this story. I hope there will be more stories like this to be told on the big screen, but I fear nothing will ever compare to the excitement before watching endgame in the midnight screening. This is what great moviemaking looks like and my wife and I laughed, cheered and cried along the way.
Thank you for this masterpiece!

I was recently introduced to the Marvel Cinematic Universe by my wife, who is a long time fan of superhero film and TV. Apart from the occasional Batman movie, superheroes never really interested me, but I am now a convert.
Taking the MCU in the context in which it is intended, as fun and family orientated entertainment, you can allow yourself to become immersed in its brilliance.
Endgame ties up the Avengers franchise perfectly, with three hours of excellent action and character interaction.
The movies starts with Deadeye/Clint Barton losing his entire family. A story line taken from the characters origin story. It is a very emotional piece of cinematography to start the movie and creates a human connection with Deadeye (played by Jeremy Renner) in his pain and eventual mission to bring his family back. Thanos is dispatched early in the film with a swift strike of Thor's axe-hammer. The movie then delves into a series of time travel events to try and undo the devastation Thanos brought to planet Earth. Of course, surprise surprise, our heroes are successful, after an incredible final battle which involves every hero of the MCU coming together. It is a wonderful sight to behold. But alas, what has been foreshadowed throughout the franchise, finally came to pass. The passing of Tony Stark. A sad moment for all Iron Man and Avengers fans, for sure. An epic money spinner? Yes of course. But nobody can deny it's value for money to entertainment ratio. Possibly the greatest super hero movie ever made and it will take something truly special to take that crown.

This is what the Marvel Cinematic Universe has been waiting for. The culmination of over 20 films in the span of 11 years telling the story of the Infinity Saga. Let me tell you that at the end of it all it was among the, in my opinion, best movies ever made. The first hour races into the story and begins the plot buildup, and although the second hour is slow, every mistake is made up for with the final hour. Such an epic battle scene ending the long, long story of the Avengers. I recommend everyone alive right now go see this movie at least once.

Warning: Spoilers ahead!I have two major criticisms about Avengers Endgame that I call the "Thanos Problem". These are:1) In Infinity War, a very serious question was asked: what should be done about overpopulation and the increasing fight for limited resources? Thanos's answer was to wipe out half of all sentient life. It is very easy to see on how many different levels this answer is flawed. In this movie, Avengers Endgame, the heroes had their own opportunity, after acquiring all the infinity stones again to address this problem in a more constructive way. It was possible for them to literally do ANYTHING they wanted to make the world a better place. With just a snap of their fingers, they could have eradicated poverty and diseases, yet they did nothing with this power. Even if that is too much, they still could have started to change the world for the better, before for example the stones would power down, and show us how much good they did. It could have been so uplifting. But no, they need to bring the stones back right away where each of them belonged.2) My other major criticism is about the character of Thanos. In Infinity War, we saw a unique villain, who had emotions and was a much more complex villain than what we usually get. In this film, Endgame, we don't see the emotional side of Thanos at all, he is reverted back to the usual one-dimensional villain. They could have explored the human side of his character a bit more for example his relationship with his daughter. If they really wanted to bring back a dead character, why not bring back Gamora, which would allow this rediscovery of Thanos's human side to evolve? She could have been teleported out before dying by the mysterious force that required a sacrifice for exchange of the Soul Stone. Then, linking up with the Avengers, they could have devised a plan to find Thanos, and convince him that what he did to the world was wrong. This could have been done by exploiting his love for his daughter, and making him see that he took away the daughters and sons of so many, who all suffer, just as he did when he lost Gamora. After realizing this, he would correct his thinking and restore everyone thus providing a substantial character development to him and give him the proper ending he deserved (as opposed to being beheaded by Thor while unarmed).The humor and visual effects are excellent, but I was expecting more from the story and buildup of the previous film.

Good things about this movie:
1. Nostalgia
2. Visuals
3. Score
4. Everything Scarlett Witch did
5. Tony with his daughter
6. Cap being worthy of mjolnirBad things about this movie:
.... pretty much everything that isn't stated above. Like,...
1. Story (Generic superhero stuff, nothing special about this movie. Relies heavily on the nostalgia factor)
2. Plot (It has so many plot holes that if I try to write them all down, it would take me a whole day to get through. Everything that is directly or indirectly related to time travel in this movie is just so wrong)
3. Character development (I didn't say characters, I said character development. Please try to understand the difference. Steve and Tony don't go through any permanent physical or psychological transformation until the very end. Fat Thor sucks in this movie. It's as lame as Nick Fury losing his eye to cat scratch. That's just unforgivable. I'm okay with professor hulk though)
4. Jokes (This movie should not have most of those jokes. That just ruins the seriousness and desperation of avengers' mission)
5. Social commentary (probably because of my own biased view on some issues)
6. Supporting characters (boring. Used only for exposition or quipping unfunny jokes in a serious situation)
7. Logical explanation of time travel theory ( I hate the fact that changing the past doesn't change the future. It just takes away the stakes that this movie is supposed to have. It's one of the worst example of lazy writing since The Last Jedi)
8. Tension building ( we already Know that Avengers will win because it's the final movie in the MCU. There was no creativity to how the avengers defeated Thanos. Iron Man builds a gauntlet that can snatch the stones from other gauntlets and harness it's powers. It was so lame)
9. Captain Marvel ( How can she breathe in space without her helmet that she wore in her solo movie? Was that just for show? Is she like Zombie Superman Princess Leia from The Last Jedi? I'm really glad that Tree Larson with her wooden plank face got less than 15 minutes of screen time)
10. Rescue (How and when did Pepper Potts learn to use the Rescue suit? )
11. Valkyrie (Where did Valkyrie got her Pegasus from? Weren't they all killed by Hela in Ragnarok? And why did Thor make her the queen of Asgardians? What makes her a worthy leader? They never showed us why she would be a better leader than Thor. When we first saw Valkyrie in Ragnarok, she was more depressed and broken down than Thor in Endgame. At least Thor didn't give up on his people like she did in her first movie)
12. Gamora (what was the point of showing little gamora and Thanos scene at the end of infinity war? Now gamora being her past self and not having any chemistry with the guardians ruins her character arc in previous two Guardians of the Galaxy movies)
13. Thanos (In infinity war Thanos was a menacing yet sympathetic villain, but in Endgame he's just another boring forgettable generic MCU villain like Malekith from The Dark World. It was a massive let down)
Spiderman (He's just a coward now. In infinity war he was brave enough to take on black order and not listening to Tony. He even defeated Ebony Maw using his brain and saved Doctor Strange's life. Now he just hides behind women's back, among them some have less experience in fighting than him)
14. Time travel suit (if time travel can't be done without quantum realm suits, how the hell did Thanos brought his whole army and himself into the future without such suits? They never showed us Ebony Maw using Pym particles for creating time machine.
15. Nebula (I wanted nebula to have more important role than she got. She's got a lot of screen time. But the interaction she has with other characters, except the ones with Tony in space, are kind of stupid and predictable)
16. The Ancient one (In doctor strange 2016 she was hesitant to teach strange because she thought he too would end up like keicillius. But in this movie which takes place in 2012 timeline, she is saying that strange is supposed to be the best among them. If that wasn't stupid enough, then just think how the hell did she know that strange would be the best sorcerer when she said that she can't see past her own death in 2016, and she died in that movie before strange defeated doormammu)
17. Mantis (what is her purpose in this movie? When all female MCU character came together to defeat Thanos, she just gave an awkward pose. That's it)
18. Hawkeye ( The whole thing in Japan didn't make sense to me. Like, what is he even doing there and why? How did Natasha find him? What happened to the spaceship that rocket gave him before time travel? Why didn't he use that in final battle against Thanos?)
19. Black widow ( she did not have a character arc like most other avengers. She's just there to sacrifice herself for the soul stone. It would have been more emotional if they had build up her relationship with Clint in a meaningful way instead of teasing about some Budapest incident audience know nothing about in Two movies and not showing us anything. In infinity war Gamora's death was tragic because they had shown us the father-daughter relationship between her and Thanos and how they care for one another. We didn't get that with Clint and Natasha. Her relationship with Cap, Tony and Banner got more screen time and had more depth than with Hawkeye. So, the whole scene in Vormir was not as emotional as Gamora's death in infinity war)
20. Rocket (how the hell did he got the reality stone from Jane? Since we know from Thor 2 that the aether can defend itself from any attacker. Even Odin and the Asgardians couldn't get it out of her body. How did rocket do it? With a taser? How did he turn aether into stone?)........
If I touch the subject of Time travel in this movie, the review would be 10x longer than this. All I can say here is that it's dumb. Seriously, who is giving this film 10 stars?

In the 70's, I grew up watching Spider Man and reading X-Men. They were groovy. Fast forward to 2008, and I saw Ironman, a character I couldn't care less about. I met my soon-to-be-wife, and she got me more involved with the MCU, and over the next several years, I backfilled my knowledge and interest into this wondrous fantasyland, eventually even caring about Captain America, who I cared even less about than Ironman.RDJ and Evans breathed humanity into their characters, as well as the rest of the tangential family I grew to appreciate and applaud. Marvel certainly had the right formula to rope me in, and care about the characters, which is the most important element of any story. The audience has to care about the characters. Even Thanos, complicated, merciless, driven and yet, somewhat understandable. Marvel did a brilliant job at sucking me into their Universe.And this all led up to Endgame. The title itself should have been a red flag. The very name of the movie signified...well...it's over. I mean, there wasn't a person on Earth who didn't know Ironman's fate. It was not a surprise or even a faint twist. He and Cap had run their course, and we were all well aware they had fulfilled their contractual obligations. We all knew it was death or retirement for most of the original Heroes.So, then. Marvel delivered exactly what had to be delivered, and nothing more. We got highs and lows. We got humor. We got drama. But we got no suspense. Everything played out exactly as it was supposed to, except it was egregiously padded with about an hour of slow, plodding, forced sentimentality.Do you know know what Ironman dying means? That's right, another 35 minutes of dull, agonizingly slow dolly shots heaped on top of the other hour of desperately boring scenes we already endured. Don't worry, though, we'll have a lifetime of Tony Stark's holographic lectures to listen to. Even in death, he wouldn't shut up.Aside from that, the deus ex machina provided by Capt'n Marvel, for whom an entire movie had to be filmed for the purpose of shoehorning her into the final battle, was an unnecessary message that "Women are just as tough as men." Thanks. We already knew that. Disney has a perpetual hard-on for lecturing us on things we already believe. I never doubted women are just as strong, if not stronger than men, as evidenced by my mom and step-mom.In fact, she should have ended the battle with her cavalcade of girls right then. She demonstrated she was more powerful than anyone else...but the Russo brothers didn't have the resolution we have, and were compelled to let her bungle it, and allow each Hero have a shot at haplessly reclaiming the bouncing glove, ricocheting nimbly out of each person's hand, extending an already painfully long battle even longer.All this, and Dr. Strange was just a second-tier afterthought, when it would have been much more compelling had he been hiding in the mirror dimension ready to unleash the Forces of the resurrected, to crush Thanos. That would have been too clever, the Russo brothers concluded, for the viewing audience.Finally, the last act Ironman performs, while struggling to complete a snap with the gauntlet, has his hand in A PERFECT POSITION TO GIVE THANOS THE FINGER, but instead declares with meek determination: "i am ironman."Other than that, great, mindless fun. The people who thought this was the greatest 11/10 movie of all time, full of awesomeness, wild feels and major sadface, are obviously children.

I don't review movies often (if at all). But for this one, I'll make an exception.
For all I know, maybe no one will read my review anyway, but here it is.People cheering for this movie, calling it perfect don't really seem to see past the ending.
The ending is good, but not great - the emotional impact wasn't really there for me. To explain why would potentially lead into spoilers, so I can't for now.
However what ultimately brings the movie down for me are the plot holes of which there are many...
I don't know how to explain more without going into examples/spoilers, so you would have to take my word for it...
Also working against the film is it's runtime and it's pacing. It starts out very slow and at the end feels like a roller coaster going down after reaching the peak. There are a million things on screen to the point of fatigue and it starts feeling like visual noise...Overall it's still a good movie, but I personally would like to watch it in privacy without a hundred or more teenagers making my head explode... So if you can, seek out a showing with the least amount of filled seats. ;)

-1 for breaking their own in-universe rules: a gauntlet that gives someone "all power" to do "anything they want" according to canon, could also bring back those killed for the soul stone; furthermore, the characters searching for the soul stone already HAD sacrificed what they loved the most, which is why they were there in the first place. -1 for killing Iron Man in the fashion they did-extremely wrong compared to the comics. Finally, the 3rd lost star is from them not having our heroes go back and grab past versions of the now-dead characters that were temporally close (example: going back to 5 minutes before Black Widow jumps and taking her to the future that is "won"), since "Dragon Ball" time travelling rules are in play, this would easily work. I almost took away another star for them not having a post-credit scene until watching a video confirming that there were "post-credit-like morsels" within the movie itself.

This review contains spoilers for Avengers: Endgame and Infinity WarWe are in the endgame now...Is there anything left to say about a movie over two billion dollars and has been a bigger topic of conversation around the world than Game of Thrones and Donald Trump?Turns out, a lot.What's this movie about?Avengers: Endgame is following the devastating events of the Infinity War. The universe is in ruins. With the remaining allies, the Avengers assemble once more in order to undo Thanos' actions and restore order to the universe.
The culmination of 10 years and 22 films. The most comprehensive mythological ever presented on the screen, an incredible range of world-class talent, and all the rest. This is the "end of the road" Tony started us on.MY OPINION:Story:
We never see our heroes like this in any other Marvel film. They know they lost and they know that they can't do anything to reverse what happened in Infinity War. As an audience, you really feel the emotion of loss of hope.Everybody is in a different location, Iron Man is trapped in space with Nebula while Captain America, Hulk, Black Widow, and other fellow Avengers are in the Avenger tower.First of all, I love this movie, but at the same time, like all the other movies in the Marvel Universe, it has the same flaws.
This is a 3-hour long movie and they made a great job balancing all the character and action moments. Phasing sometimes is a little off, but that's okay because it doesn't distance you out from the movie.
In the beginning, Captain Marvel saves Tony Stark in the first 10 minutes of the movie and that to me is just lazy writing. It was too fast and it doesn't give you the time to acknowledge that these characters are in real danger. Another issue that I have with this movie is that Ant-Man is saved by a rat. I don't know whose idea that was, but we had some theories of how Ant-Man could return from the quantum realm and is this really what they gave us? We're supposed to believe that Ant-Man is saved by a rat. I just don't buy this stuff in movies.Characters:Let's talk about characters since this movie is heavily about the story and character ark. Characters are always brilliantly written and balanced throughout the whole film. They took some risks with two characters which could have turned out pretty bad, but somehow they managed to find the perfect way to do it. Of course, I'm talking about Thor and Hulk ( Bruce Banner ). I loved both of the characters. What they have changed felt quite ambitious and hilarious, although I sometimes miss the old Hulk smashing things like the good old days.
This film is heavily focused on Iron Man ( Tony Stark ) and Captain America ( Steve Rogers ). What they have done with these two characters is just wonderful and brilliant. In the beginning, you feel the tension between these two characters because of what happened in the Civil War. One of Tony's iconic line this movie proposed was " I love you 3000 " which added this film something special. Considering how Hawkeye's relationship with his daughter was described, this line emphasized it all perfectly. Tony's sacrifice at the end when he took all the infinity stones and snapped his finger killing Thanos and his army was very well done. And Tony's final line " I AM IRON MAN " added another layer of emotion to that moment. His final line is a reference to the very first Iron Man film that created this huge universe. Marvel finds the perfect way to end Tony's ark and it couldn't be any better. His monologue at the end was so meaningful and precious. In the end, as an audience, you understand and admit that this is the end of the Iron Man storyline.Captain America's story arc didn't fall behind Iron Man's in any manner. In this movie, Marvel finds a perfect way to end Captain America's ark. In the beginning, he is hopeless like all the fellow Avengers. He adds this film so much heart and emotion. At the final battle, we saw Captain America hold the Mjollnir which was an awesome moment. We saw Captain America move Mjholiner a little bit in Avengers: Age of Ultron and it was even better to see Captain America finally lift and hold Mjollnir which proves that he is finally worthy. After Hulk snapped and got every hero back in action Captain America says " AVENGERS ASSEMBLE ", this moment was something to be experienced. After the final battle, Captain America had to bring the stones back to fix different timelines. After that, we are seeing old Captain America which left us confused, but soon after that, we learn that after he puts the stones back to their original locations, he lived his full life with his only love Agent Carter. When he finally returns as an old man back to his timeline, he gives his shield to Falcon when everyone thought it was gonna be Bucky, but I thought it was a great moment between Captain America and Falcon. The movie ends with Captain America and Agent Carter dancing in the past which was a reference to the first Captain America film similar to the reference mentioned about Iron Man earlier. It was a great ending for Captain America's character ark. It couldn't end any better. It was a wonderful and bittersweet ending.Time Travel:Now it's the time for the main concept that everyone is talking about, which is time travel.
This is not an ordinary time travel film like Back to the Future. At the beginning of this film, we find out that Thanos used the stones again on another planet. Our heroes are once more going to try to get the stones from Thanos, but when they arrive they are learning that Thanos used the stones to destroy the stones. Then the film cuts to five years later...
Our heroes are desperate and try to move on some do, but not them. All of a sudden Ant-Man appears and talks about the possibilities of time travel. After Tony changes his decision and joins the team again for the possibilities of time travel. After they find out how time travel works they are going back in time and the movie turns into a time heist.Time travel is a risky thing to do in any movie because it has science behind it and if you change the rules of time travel people will judge every little thing, in the end, it could be a bad choice for your film. In this film, they change the rules and not everything makes sense, but after they explained how it works in this universe it started to makes more sense. This is a superhero movie after all not everything will going to make sense and that's okay. After they went back on time the movie shines and we as an audience are experiencing the old MCU films once again which was an awesome moment to experience in the theater. Our heroes are traveling different timelines through MCU the reason is they are trying to restore the stones before Thanos for the sake of the universe. Hawkeye and Natasha went to Vormir to get the soul stone, but they didn't know the requirements for the soul stone. Then we as audience witnessing the terrible event that happened to Natasha aka Black Widdow. She sacrifices herself for the soul stone which was a shocking moment that I didn't see coming. After all, this is a fun, ambitious, different and emotional time heist superhero film.CONCLUSION:In the end, this is a brilliantly written, well-directed and well-acted action-packed superhero film that fans were waiting for. Sometimes passing is little off and there are some lazy moments and not all the time travel stuff makes sense, but as a whole, it just works and creates a whole different superhero experience for the audience. I love this movie and every superhero fan will enjoy this movie. This is the end of the journey Tony had started us on and it ended beautifully.Rating: 9/10

So when he arrives everyone who vanished 5yrs ago should still be there and there is no need for Hulk to do the snap??Anyway, loved it, gutted for some of the deaths, but end of an era!!!

This movie has a half-dozen amazing scenes, a dozen great lines and two dozen great moments. But, it left me unfulfilled. First, the great. The elevator scene is one of the best in all the Marvel movies. Captain America using his cleverness to outwit Hydra. The fight against his younger self is great too. As is the hammer moment. Peter getting knocked out by Nebula and War Machine was hilarious. The opening scene with Hawkeye was a punch to the gut. The moment where all the heroes return near the end is overwhelming. There are other moments that really shine. I found myself Involuntarily clapping many times.But, the movie fails to deliver satisfying conclusions to most of its characters. Turns out Cap never sacrificed anything at all in the end. He lived 70 years with the woman he loved. All while leaving Bucky to be tortured (not to mention sitting idly by while numerous other atrocities occurred).
Kids, it's also cool to play video games all day and leave your responsibilities. Even if you have god like powers and people rely on you and hope for better days. You do you, and put someone else in charge so that you can do the hard work of threatening little kids on Fortnite. You know, the real important things in life.
Speaking of life, the soul stone requires an "everlasting" sacrifice of what you love. Except it doesn't. No one dies in the MCU. Not for long anyway. Why morn the loss of Loki for the third time. He's alive, duh. Why give vision and Black Widow a funeral, or wake or at least a eulogy? They didn't. The film does not care about these two characters deaths. Why should the audience.
And are they really dead? Just go back in time with the Pym particles anytime you want and, poof, they're alive. You could visit anytime you want to. Iron Man saw his dad. Hawkeye heard his daughter's voice. And that half of the Universe thing. No worries, they are all alive. In the end, all the bad guys dies and three Avengers.But, those three Avengers will stay dead for how long?
Does anyone seriously think they are really dead? As in forever? Or course not. In five years, all three of them will be in a Marvel movie again. So don't cry too hard, no one dies forever (in the MCU that is).
Absolutely speecheless. Magnificant. Go watch now!

This might be the best movie of the year for me. Tons of great films this year but none of them has impacted me like this one did. This is by far the greatest MCU film and it'll probably always be. I loved everyone's performance, yes even Brie Larson's, I loved the visuals and I really  loved the sound design, soundtrack and just the movie in general. 10/10 easy.

The thing that the writers and editors did so well in Infinity War was splicing all the mini subplots together. It was written and directed so well that it didn't feel disjointed or clunky. Endgame tried to do the same and failed. There were some plot holes and clucky awkward scenes with strange pacing. There were too many pop-culture references which is lazy writing and the jokes came off half-assed.
The plot itself wasn't about beating Thanos and restoring peace, it was more concerned with tieing up all the little plot ends for each character. Which became tiresome by the 3rd act. When the war broke in the 3rd act it felt like it had already been done in Infinity War. Apart from the restored characters (which was nice) it felt like they were showing that scene for the sake of it. Oh here's another battle, let's go kick some ass! rolls eyes... The message was clear; war, bad... We're all stronger together, if we put aside our differences and stand together we're better than the sum of our parts. Which is why it was confusing at the height of the battle the men and women were shown succeeding separately instead of teams working together. Which is quite relevant in today's political climate.
The ending was nice even if it was an easy way to finish it. What's better than a hero? A dead hero... As cynical as that may sound, the ending with Tony Starck narrating through the ending was a nice touch to the end of an epic era.
Now I'll have to rewatch them all from the first one, where it all began, inside of a cave...

I walked out of the cinema and rode home on my bike. It was raining outside - oh how poetic - and I had a smile on my face. In the next moment I had tears in my eyes. Then I was smiling again.
Funny, what a movie can do to you.
In that moment I felt infinitely grateful to be born in this time. I mean, I could have been born around 1600. I would have had the chance to watch Shakespeare plays live. But I'm pretty happy to watch what must be todays equivalent of a Shakespeare play. I just witnessed a cinematic masterpiece. But not just that. I had the feeling I just experienced a final step and the end of an era.If you think Infinity War was overwhelming in it's quantity of superheroes in one place, then, oh boy, you've no idea what's coming for you. You think you're prepared for this movie? Think again, you're not.
Endgame is a new level.
In some regards it's more of an Avengers movie than the previous one. We're very limited in our assembly of heroes. It really focuses on our beloved six.Clint got a rogue makeover. The scene where he lost his family was really heartbreaking. You can understand his motives. He's clearly in distress. He needs to be woken up by Natasha to get onto the right path, again. But when he's awake Hawkeye is the hero that we once met.Natashas development from deadly assassin who works for scrupulous leaders to a leader who holds her new found family together and sacrifices herself to protect this family is one of the most incredible character arches to watch. Truth be told I never expected her to be the sacrificing one.
The MCU lost its greatest badass. Black Widow, I'm going to miss you.Thor! Please, get back into shape. I mean think of all the fun Loki would be making of you if he could see you! Brother, have you swallowed a planet? (Well, Loki is still dead, but he still managed to steel some moments in the true God of Mischief fashion. Wherever you are I hope the sun is shining on you and could you please not be dead? That would be great, thank you! I mean really, you have to be alive - somehow. Are you sure you checked that you really don't have a heartbeat?) Thor is the one who takes the finger snap the hardest and drowns his sorrows in alcohol which shows in his not so fit form than what we're used to. It's one of the funniest aspects of the whole movie. In general this movie is not just epic, it's funny in moments that are totally serious. With a little bit of mummys help you got yourself together again.
You couldn't resist, could you? You just had to get MjÃ¶lnir back.
The decision to join the Guardians of the Galaxy... oh how much potential I see.No Hulk in the last movie, therefore more Hulk in this one. A very different Hulk. I think Bruce Banner did something, that nobody expected. He accepted the Hulk as something that is a part of himself. Not as the green rage monster, but as something that isn't a mistake but a gift. A great massage: accept your faults and turn them into something beautiful. Embrace them and be proud.Captain America, you fought Red Skull, you fought Iron Man, you fought Thanos and now you fought yourself. Now you're worthy enough to wield MjÃ¶lnir. Truth be told it was the most beautiful and epic moment of my fangirl life to watch you pick up that hammer. It's a moment that I'll never forget. You're worthy of another big part of a heroes life. After years of fighting and suffering you're finally worthy enough to get your happy end. Steve, I'm so unbelievably happy for you and Peggy. You gave your shield to Sam. America, you have a new Captain.
Sam, be sure, we will follow you to the end of the line.Iron Man, to be honest I didn't like you when I first watched Iron Man. With time you grew on me. Now I can't imagine the MCU without you. But sadly it's a thought that we all have to live with. You're the beginning and the end of the whole infinity saga. You're the heart of the Avengers. Now more than ever.
And you invented time travel. Which definitely makes you the coolest Avenger.
Tony Stark, who gained the most after Thanos finger snap and lost the most while attempting to undo it. We should all pay our respect to the genius, billionaire, playboy (now married and the father of one daughter) and philanthropist that was Tony Stark.
Tony, I assure you, we will remember you.One in particular will do that.
Guess who's back? Spider Man!
And everybody else!
But most importantly Spider Man! You had like what? Three minutes of screen time? It's an accomplishment that you managed to leave tears in my eyes nearly every time I saw you. Especially your reunion with Tony was a moment of genuin happiness. The moment of your goodbye was a moment of genuine sadness.
Seeing you again... that was nice. Thank you for coming back, I guess. You can make all the tears up to me with a hell of a movie in July this year.Ladies and gentleman, it seems the superhero business finally understood that women can kick ass just as well as man. The symbolic act of gathering every female character together in one scene and let them kick Thanos in his purple behind, should be an eyeopener. Beware, everybody who lives under a rock and thinks a woman belongs in a kitchen, there are woman out there with brains and skills you could never imagine and together we will come for you.Often small people aren't taken seriously. I should know that, because I'm not that tall of a person myself. So it took me great satisfaction to see that small, underrated Ant-Man brings us the solution to this whole mess. Remember: especially small people can have the biggest impact.It's quite poetic, ironically tragic, how Thanos finds his end. Well, both times are. Thor took his advise and aimed for the head. The rest is dust in the wind.People might say it's an overly long attempt of making money with a storyline that took ten years to set up, an overwhelming amount of characters and too many references to all the other MCU movies. Well, my response to those people is: I don't care. Because I look at what this movie does with those who watch it. And what I see amazes me. I'm a strong believer that the fictional world is in some regards real because the fans let it become a realistic thing.
There are people who join you because you're your annoying self, sit through this three hour long epos and laugh with you even though you had to explain to them what was going on during the movie.
There are men sitting behind you in the cinema who don't even try to hide their tears when their favorite superhero dies.
When the whole theater gasps, cries out and is nearly getting a heart attack every time someone throws a punch at one of our heroes, because they can't stand watching them get hurt, you know you're sitting in a brillant and mind blowing MARVEL movie.
Give me one other movie franchise that has accomplished that. I dare you.I think superhero movies have this prejudice that they are supposed to be simple. There is a good and a bad guy. They fight and in the end the good guy wins. It's not like that anymore. MARVEL changed that. The whole MCU connects so many dynamics, storylines and characters that you really are lost if you don't watch all movies. It's quite clever. You have to watch every MARVEL movie to get the full experience in the end. So yes, some people will watch this movie and be completely confused in some scenes, because we're taking a trip down memory lane through a lot of MARVEL movies. But that's not what this movie stands for. It's not for falling asleep halfway through the movie or leaving the cinema before the credits roll down.
This movie is a gift, a treasure and a reward for all the love and passion and tears, for all those who stuck with MARVEL for the last ten years.
The ones who watched every minute and sat through every end credit scene just to get a few more seconds out of the movie.
It's for those who where in awe when Captain America was turned into a super soldier; who had goose-pimples when the Avengers first assembled, who fell a little bit more in love with Loki than with Thor, who where torn during the Civil War and wanted to protect Spider Man in his fight against the Vulture.
It's for everybody who felt like their heart was just ripped out of their chest after Infinity War.
We get a thank you, a band aid and a promise for much more to come.The end is not pleasing, there are things that could've been better, people that could've survived and people that could've come back.
But I think it's the best possible and most perfect end that we could've gotten out of all options. And there were fourteen million six hundred five other options. If this is what it takes to win, I take it. Where Infinity War was a brutal crushing of all our hearts, Endgame was the difficult task to put all of us back together, to reunite what was torn apart, to mend what was broken. It was as challenging as the collection of all the infinity stones for the avengers.
But it worked.
It's not undone. All the chaos not just disappeared, Infinity War wasn't simply erased. There are still broken parts and pieces, the events are going to leave scars.
But our family is back together again.
To quote Iron Man: Â»Part of the journey is the end.Â«
But an end doesn't have to be sad. Look at the Avengers:
One gets his peace.
One gets his time back.
One accepts himself for what he is.
One gets the chance to recover from his loses.
One protects her family.
One gets his family back for good.
If you look at it like that, I think everybody got their happy end.
An end can also be the start of a new beginning.There was an idea to bring together a group of remarkable people, see if they could become something more. See if they could work together when we needed them to to fight the battles we never could.
They could.
Earth mightiest heroes avenged us.
All is well.
The sun is shining again - on all of us.There is just one more thing to say:
Thank you, Avengers!

My review of Avengers Endgame:The best MCU movie. The theatre went totally nuts. It had spectacular action. It was surprisingly funny, and emotionally captivating. It manages a large roster of well developed characters very well executed, everyone gets a moment to shine. Delightful throwbacks to previous outings as well as smartly placed pop culture references. A truly satisfying finale for the 22movie and 10 year story arc which we have loved. Refreshed rating.

I never thought that a comic book movie could make me cry, and Avengers: Endgame made me cry... several times. I was a little skeptical at first at the fact the movie was over three hours long, and that they couldn't tell what needed to be told without it feeing rushed, but I was so wrong. Avengers: Endgame is the perfect ending to a beloved story that has lasted over ten years, it makes all the right choices and ticks all the boxes. For the first time in a while a movie surprised me not only once but 10 times, for once twists actually feel like a twist, they're not predictable as most movies are now-a-days. The casts performances made these once cheesy and quirky comic book characters feel like more human, showing some of the finest and convincing acting ever put to screen. The movies serious moments are jaw-dropping, but that still doesn't mean that theres no humour, in fact Endgame nearly has as much comedy in it as guardians of the galaxy. I loved the second act simply because it was cool and interesting to see past MCU movies from a different perspective. then the climax happens, and theres more 'war' in the climax than there is in the whole of 'infinity war', The climax has some of the most stunning action sequences in movie history. Robert Downey Jr was the perfect choice to kill of, simply because the person who started it all, should be the one to end it, his final words "I am Iron Man" really got me crying, but it didn't make me cry as much as the very last scene, with captain America finally getting his dance with Peggy Carter, something that we've all been wanting for eight years since Captain America: the first Avenger. With that being said, Avengers: Endgame is an emotional and bitter sweet way to end the saga that has come close to all our hearts, it's a wild ride through everything we've been through over this long decade, with it's phenomenal performances, beautiful script, stunning effects, suspenseful action, brilliant script and top quality cinematography; Avengers: Endgame will go down in history as the final piece of the puzzle to the most beloved franchise of all time, its perfection amongst the millions of movies that have been made, it will be remembered until the end of days as a cinematic masterpiece.
This movie is the culmination of 21 movies for over 10 years in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

The whole concept of time travel adds more questions than it answers.But I have never, nor will I ever again, experience something like this. There are moments in this film that probably won't ever be topped. Several of them. It evokes every possible emotion, to the point where I still don't know how to feel.The best way I can describe this film is by saying I cannot describe it. What else can I say? This picture is great. If I could, I would give it an 8.5/10, since there are flaws; no film has none, yet is a fun ride with humor, action, chills, and tragedy. Truly, a cinematic experience to remember.Yet still, out of Infinty War, Endgame is less in one major way, which is the biggest flaw this film has: Thanos. While a terrifcily written and seemingly unstoppable villian in IW, Thanos in Endgame is...just less. He isn't as fleshed out, especially during the first act, as he was in IW, and he is almost disappointing. In fact, most of the first hour and maybe hour and a half are. While I enjoyed the first couple of hours, could've been better paced and a good ten minutes coulve been edited out. In other words, it was kinda slow.As the second act ends, however, it goes from a tender 4 or 5 to a 12. It becomes the climax of not just one film, but 22, 11 years in the making. Without spoling, the final battle is amazing, cahotic and surprisingly violent for a Marvel Film.All in all, this is a fantastic ending to a great and quite frankly revolutionary film series, and I guarantee you will at least shed one tear. It has its flaws, which are sadly charecter related, but they don't drag the film through the mud. At a three hour runtime with this many characters, it makes sense that the Russos couldn't do everything perfectly. All in all, this film gets a 85/100.TIP: Don't sit through the entirety of credits, for there is no after scene, no thank you to the fans and no tribute to Sir Stan Lee, sadly. So don't waste your time and sit for 10 minutes.

No spoiler brief review for fans and non fans:-If you are a Marvel fan, then you know you shouldn't miss this movie so please watch it before anyone spoils it for you. Even if someone does spoil it, the movie is worth watching for its spectacular special effects, music by Alan Silvestri and stellar performances by the cast. The 3D version of the movie is nice as the 3D effect adds additional depth to the fight scenes and space scenes. It's a movie that has so many scenes which feel like they are there to please the fans and the scenes have a lot of emotional impact because of the character development as well as back-story that have built up the emotions throughout the years. This movie is something that should be kept in your DVD or Blu-Ray collections when officially released later on, as there are so many things in this movie which will make you want to revisit it and relive the moments. You will not get bored by this movie and might as well watch it twice or even more times in the theater.If you are not a Marvel fan or haven't watched any of the Marvel movies, the movie does tell you what happened in the Avengers Infinity War and even if you won't be able to identify with some of the characters, you can guess that Avengers are the good people and they are trying to stop the bad guy, Thanos from conquering the world and also to try and repair what he did in the Infinity War movie. The movie is worth watching for its special effects, acting, music and great production value. Some character decisions might divide the audience, so how you feel will depend on your personal attachment and expectations form a particular super hero character's story arc.This is the last Russo Bros. Marvel film according to a GamesRadar Interview and the last Stan Lee cameo (RIP). Go watch it!

The film begins straight 3 weeks after the events of Infinity War with Captain Marvel rescuing Iron Man and Nebula and bringing them to Earth. IM doesn't want anything to do with the Avengers anymore so doesn't go with the rest of the team to hunt down Thanos who's now living on some distant planet. The Avengers along with CM get to the planet to find out that the Gauntlet with the stones has been destroyed along with the stones so that no one can undo what Thanos has done. At this moment Thor chops off Thanos' head and you then realise that the rest of the film isn't going to be about how to get back at Thanos. Remember this is in the very first 20 minutes.Fast forward 5 years and the Avengers have all moved on to other priorities in their lives and only BW and CA are running the Avengers. As luck would have it, a rat walks over the controls of the quantum machine thing and out pops Ant Man from the end of the last Ant Man film. He then teams up with BW and CA to reassemble the Avengers and go back in time to get the stones and undo what Thanos has snapped. The rest of the film is how the stones are recovered and how everything is resolved. This is my main gripe with this film, time travel...I always feel that films that feature time travel or alternate universes use this as an easy way to get around problems and issues with the story. They ended the previous film with killing off half the characters and then thought how can we bring them back? I know we'll just go back in time and sort everything out. Don't get me wrong, I love time travel films, one of my all-time favourites is back to the future, as long as time travel is what the theme of the story is, but to use time travel as an easy excuse to give the Heroes an advantage is the lazy option. Recently the re-booted Star Trek being an example of an alternate universe which just didn't have the same emotional connect as the original series as very easily everything that has been shown can just be erased/altered with time travel and introducing an alternate universe. If you want to watch a good series that uses alternate universes then I would highly recommend searching out Fringe which was shown around 10 years ago.So now we've established time travel is what the major portion of this film is going to be could we please stop referencing older time travel films just so the makers can poke fun at their own stupid idea before the audience does. The amount of times Back to the future is called upon is sometimes a bit shameful. This film gives you so much de ja vu that you know that you've seen this before, BKF2 anyone. There's even a scene reminding you of Doc's explanation to Marty about scewing the timeline. It's a shame Marvel couldn't think of any other way to get back at Thanos other than resorting to time travel. Also, why not just time travel back with CM to when Thanos was about to snap and add her into the fight as well? Would be a lot easier than trying to get the stones back one by one! Also, this time machine they devise not only lets you travel through time but also lets you change your geographical location, amazing! But I will say this, on the flip side using time travel to revisit the past films is the best way to tie everything in and a chance for some serious fan service!So once the stones are recovered Iron Man does the snap again and the entire Avengers characters return for one last bad ass battle with Thanos. Here there are some great action set pieces and the majority of the characters get their own small part to play, especially during the whole 'rugby' sequence with the new gauntlet. But the flaw here is that Iron Man uses the gauntlet to do the snap and not Thor or Hulk who are more powerful. But obviously Marvel wanted to end this infinity stone saga with the death of Iron Man as it started with Iron Man back in 2008. So a well justified send off for the character and also now not having to pay Robert Downey Jr so much either. I'd like to say the following, a more emotional ending during Iron Man's death scene would have been having Thor, CA, Hulk, and Hawkeye kneeling around Iron Man and at this point CA and IM shake hands to put aside their differences and then Gwyneth's character saying her line. Currently you see CA and Thor crying at IM's death but you don't really get a sense of where they're stood. Where's BW you ask? She died trying to get the soul stone and doesn't even get a funeral scene!So to summarise, even though there are so many flaws with the story and screenplay, being over 3 hours long, because you're 11 years and 22 films deep into this saga you easily brush over the minus points and only leave the cinema with plus points. The film is a cinematic gem and the final hour or so more than makes up for the short comings mentioned earlier.As an afterthought, the ending of the film shows CA not coming back to his reality after returning the stones to the respective points in time and instead living his life through to an old man with Agent Carter. Could this mean then that what we are now seeing is not the same universe but an alternate universe where things are now changed? How else would an easier solution be to include the X-Men into the MCU now that Disney has bought 20th Century Fox?

This movie has a lot of great things going for it. It has its typical mcu comedic charm despite the atmosphere of defeat. It definitely has things that will make you tear up a bit, especially compared to previous movies. The action, while in my opinion was scarce compared to previous movies, was still fun to watch.My biggest cons to the movie are the following:
1. Fat thor
2. Limited action scenes
3. Most of all, time travelFat thor was funny at first but I was really hoping he would whip into shape. Instead I just couldn't take him serious which is a shame because he's such a cool character.The action scenes just seemed to be resolved so quick. I was hoping this war would be an epic battle of like lord of the rings: the return of the king proportion. Instead we get a big build up, with quick resolution. I find it incredibly convenient that the whole squad works to get the new infinity gauntlet to the portal and even with captain marvels ability to fly it still lands next to thanos. I mean come on..Then there's the time travel. I wish I could list every single plot hole that comes along with time travel in this movie. A lot just doesn't make sense. Like why wouldn't simply bringing one stone to the future prevent anyone from disappearing in the first place? Thanos would never had completed the gauntlet. There's a multitude of other examples that just ruin it for me the more I think about other plot holes. It's a shame I think they built it up so well in infitity war. Time travel is such a cop out to resolve things, I hate that they had to use it here.But all in all this movie is definitely worth the theater visit. I enjoyed watching it, but when I read that it is getting tens? I think people are just giving it that out of the hype of the movie instead really critically thinking about its flaws.

Being a Marvel Fan, I am happy with the movie. The movie had some great moments a Fan could wish for. But the expectation from the movie especially after the performance of Infinity War (a mind blowing movie: 10/10) were not fulfilled. The movie literally had so many loop holes and lacked logic at many critical points that I couldn't really enjoy the positives as much as I did for Infinity War.I watched the Movie in IMAX 3D, so obviously the viewing experience was awesome as the movie was shot very well, the cinematography, the VFX, the action scenes, etc. were really great (10/10). But then came in time travel and they took a stand on the concept of time travel different from any other movie. Even that is fin as they have the freedom. But then repeatedly, at every crucial point they violated the rules that they set themselves. The concept of creating a parallel timeline, the concept of not effecting your present by travelling to the past was all lost when they started collecting the stones.
The same issue is with Captain Marvel altering the time line at the end of the movie.Another problem is the idea of how Thanos with such a huge army travelled through time to the present using just 1 vial of Pym particle and with no available technology of using the Pym Particle is beyond digestion. They need to explain that part as everything relies on that.There are many other loop holes and errors (I have counted more that 10 major-major issues). But the movie had many positive points. Professor Hulk finally appeared as expected. A base for Ronan has been set. Almost everyone is back for the Last Battle. And sadly, Iron man is dead (that another problem with the logic of the movie).No doubt that many movie have loop holes, but it wasn't expected at such a large scale of this Movie. It was a 10/10 because of the battles, because of the acting, etc. But it lost 2 crucial points because of the flawed storyline. The movie is an emotional sine curve, it has moment of anxiety, joy, horror, sadness, excitement, etc. But surely it's not a 'Movie of the Generation' or a 'Masterpiece'. I feel Infinity war deserves and keeps these titles.But worth a watch, and do watch it in IMAX, you would love the battles.

Avengers Endgame was a good movie. I don't know what it could've done differently. It had action, comedy, drama, and big surprises. Everyone had a chance to get their story told on screen and be the main focus. I did feel though that sometimes the movie did drag on a little, but it was necessary to get the characters emotions across.
For some reason I could not stand any scene with Captain Marvel. She just had this intense arrogance about her that rubbed me the wrong way, considering every other character was already fully developed by the time she arrives onto the scene. The story was great, it had the perfect blend of comedy, and drama that just kept things flowing. Although whenever it came to the drama, I did get a little bored. I love drama, but these moments just felt like they were taking forever.
Also, I feel the battle scenes could've been more intense. They were too far and few in between. I enjoyed the ending, it brought closure whether you liked it or not. I feel with movies like these, movies that bring an end to something that has been built up over soo many years, is always going to give you a sense of dissatisfaction. I don't know if it's because of the sadness that it's all over, or maybe the story didn't play out how you wanted too. I don't know where that feeling comes from, but this gave that to me.
I don't really have to say whether you should watch it or skip it because unless you're living under a rock, you've either watched it or are going to watch it.
I gave this movie an 8/10. It was a good movie, but I felt Infinity Wars was better in terms of delivery, battle scenes and excitement. Check it out for yourself.
